n:
President Donald Trump‚Äôs campaign tweeted accusations claiming that James Blalock of Covington, who is deceased, voted in the election.¬†
¬†‚ÄúThe only problem? He passed away 14 years ago. Sadly, Mr. Blalock is a victim of voter fraud,‚Äù the tweet reads.
The accusations were amplified on national television.
‚ÄúMr. Blalock was a mailman for 33 years until he passed away in 2006. Fourteen years later, according to state records, he was still mailing things. James Blalock cast a ballot in last week‚Äôs election,‚Äù Tucker Carlson said in a clip and story labeled on¬†Fox News' website as an opinion piece.¬†
However, 11Alive was able to find out that James Blalock did not vote in last week‚Äôs election. Mrs. James Blalock did vote.

d: How Apple made its new M1 chip, the latest MacBooks ‚Äì and used its past to decide its future ‚Ä¢ The Independent
n:
Andrew Griffin:

it‚Äôs still the case that fans repeatedly speculated that Apple was going to do something more profound to the Mac: turn it into something like the iPad, for instance, or use the transition to radically alter how its laptops work. Apple has repeatedly insisted that it thinks the laptop form factor is valuable and distinct from touchscreens like the iPad, but people haven‚Äôt always believed them. This has led to ideas including the theory that Apple had redesigned its new macOS to make way for touch screen Macs. The Big Sur aesthetic borrows from the iPhone and iPad ‚Äì buttons are bigger, with more space, which numerous commentators pointed out would make them perfect for manipulating with your fingers ‚Äì but not because of some secret plan to change the way the Mac works, [Apple software chief Craig] Federighi says. ‚ÄúI gotta tell you when we released Big Sur, and these articles started coming out saying, ‚ÄòOh my God, look, Apple is preparing for touch‚Äô. I was thinking like, ‚ÄòWhoa, why?‚Äô ‚ÄúWe had designed and evolved the look for macOS in a way that felt most comfortable and natural to us, not remotely considering something about touch. ‚ÄúWe're living with iPads, we're living with phones, our own sense of the aesthetic ‚Äì the sort of openness and airiness of the interface ‚Äì the fact that these devices have large retina displays now. All of these things led us to the design for the Mac, that felt to us most comfortable, actually in no way related to touch. ‚ÄúI've never felt more comfortable moving across our family of devices as a user, which I do hundreds of times a day than I do now, moving between iOS 14, iPadOS 14, and macOS Big Sur. They all just feel of a family ‚Äì there's just less cognitive load to the switching process. ‚ÄúIt's just they all feel like the natural instantiation of the experience for that device. And that's what you're seeing not some signaling of a future change in input methods.‚Äù

That seems pretty specific that Apple's not going to make the Mac touchable. But what does that mean for iOS apps running on it? And you know too that when they decide that they are going to make it touch-based - well, the time was just right. A couple of years off at least though.

d: Metatrends shaping the next decade | by Peter Diamandis | Nov, 2020 | Medium
Why Matthew Yglesias Left Vox - The Atlantic
n: Yglesias felt that he could no longer speak his mind without riling his colleagues. His managers wanted him to maintain a ‚Äúrestrained, institutional, statesmanlike voice,‚Äù he told me in a phone interview, in part because he was a co-founder of Vox. But as a relative moderate at the publication, he felt at times that it was important to challenge what he called the ‚Äúdominant sensibility‚Äù in the ‚Äúyoung-college-graduate bubble‚Äù that now sets the tone at many digital-media organizations.
